While the Biden Administration has been working to improve TSA‚Äôs workforce, codifying these rights in law is the right thing to do for its 60,000 workers ‚Äì and the right thing to do for national security.

Since the beginning of COVID, TSA‚Äôs Transportation Security Officers have not only kept our skies safe, but have been risking their lives while serving on the frontlines. 36 TSA employees have died from COVID.
For 20 years, TSA screeners have been unable to access the same workforce rights afforded to other Federal employees ‚Äì and are among the lowest paid. TSA also faces high attrition and low morale.
These rights include full Federal employee collective bargaining rights, access to an independent third party for dispute resolution, and improved compensation under the General Schedule wage system.

Today the House is set to pass HR 903, Chairman @BenniegThompson‚Äôs bipartisan Rights for the TSA Workforce Act, to give @TSA‚Äôs frontline workers who keep our skies secure the same basic rights and protections afforded to other Federal workers under Title 5.
